blocks.text:
Susan B. Anthony
Speeches & Writings File
'Judge Taney' 1861Judge Taney
1861The decision of Judge Taney, that 'Black men have no rights which white men are bound to respect,' is not, after all, so wide off the mark. It is but the reflection of the spirit and practice of the American people.
All over our country, in the nominally Free states if the North, as well as the slave-owning states of the South, the rights of the black men are disregarded, trampled under the foot of the white man.
In the southern half of this [slavery accursed- strike through] Union, [there are nearly Four Millions of- strike through] native born [citizens, so called black- strike through] men, women & children, [who- strike through] fromthe very hour of their birth, are defrauded of every right to life, liberty & the pursuit of happiness. And this too, by the sanction of both Church and state.

In the Fifteen slave-owning states of the south, there are Four millions of so called black men please to remember, that very many of them, have faces as white as yours or mine - the result of the terrible wholesale system of licentiousness practiced there - who have no right to their own persons, no right to the earnings of their own hands, no right to the development of their own intellects, no right to the exercise of theirown consciences and wills, no right to any of the sacred relations of life. The holy ties of husband & wife, parents & children, brothers & sisters, may be severed at any moment, at the will of the tyrant master. Not a thought, word, action or aspiration, can the slave call his own, all, ALL are the property of another.

Yes: in those fifteen slave states, there are four millions of human beings, in many of whose veins courses the proud saxon blood of Virginia's noblest sons, who are driven to unpaid toil, from the rising to the setting of the sun, who4
are beaten in body, and lacerated
in spirit, - who are
bought and sold in the market,
with as little regard to family
ties, as the farmer evinces in the
sale of horses & sheep. And if,
perchance, any show discontent,
and rise in rebellion to such
galling bondage, or with fleeing
footstep turn northward to Victoria's
Asylum for the oppressed, they
are hunted with blood hounds,
shot dead by the slave hunter,
hung by the dozzens, without Judge
or Jury - nay more, burned
alive — And all these terrible
crimes may be perpetrated upon
the [blacks, In the] black men & women
and children of the South, with

5
perfect impunity, provided, none
but slaves witness the deed. -
For, by the Laws of the Slave
States, the testimony of a slave
against his master, or any white
person, is not allowed in the
Courts. Thus are these
Four illions of American Citizens,
these Four Millions of Gods
children, by the white man's
law of state, and sanction of
Church, despoiled of every right,
sacred to the soul of man.
And, that too, not only by the
laws of the Fifteen Slave States,
and the will of the cruel
Slave-holder, but by the united
consent of the sixteen non-slave-holding
states, and of every indi-6
individual citizen thereof, who swears
allegiance to the United States
Constitution, or is a loyal citizen
to the United States Government.
Thus much for Judge Taney's decision
and the South.
(Now to our own nominally
Free States of the North.)
Travel with me from Maine
to Minesota, and visit the
numerous popular & powerful public institutions,
established for the advancement
of Industry, Education, Literature,
the arts and sciences, -
also, those for Religious, Benevolent,
and Charitable purposes, and
see what a vast proportion
of them, exclude from their
advantages, all persons of color.7
Indeed, so universal is
this proscription, throughout the
entire north, that I know of
but two regularly Endowed Colleges
that admit colored students on
terms of perfect equality - and
those two, Oberlin of Ohio, and
M. Granville of N.Y. - are the only
Colleges, that to my knowledge, have
been denied an apropriation from
the state. And all this injustice,
too, is practiced toward
colored men & women, who
are property-holders, & whom the
law compels [them] to pay taxes,
to help build, endow & support,
the very institutions from which
white men so cruelly exclude them.8
But, say you, separate schools
are established at the expense of the public
treasury, in nearly all the cities
and larger villages of the Free
states, where colored children
are duly cared for. - Grant
that there are colored schools -
go visit them, and you will
find them in the most unpleasant
localities, in the oldest & most
inconvenient buildings, and presided
over by the lowest grade of
teachers. In very many instances
persons are placed over those
school, whos hearts are devoid of the
first fellow feeling for the children.
Yes, we do have colored schools,
and why; simply because colored
children are considered unfit to

9
occupy the same school rooms,
recite in the same classes, compete
for the same prizes, and
perchance, snatch the Laurels
from the fairer brows of the sons
and daughters of the proud white
man. Yes, we do have colored
schools, and for no other reason
save, that of disrespect for the
black man's rights.
In very many of our
northern cities, colored people
are not allowed to ride in
the Omnibuses, or Rail Road Cars.
At our Hotels, from the St. Nicholas
& Revere, [House] down to the lowest
grade, colored people are refused
first class accommodations. It matters
not, what their worth or wealth, they
must, every where, be made to feelthat they belong to a hated an

10
that they belong to a hated and
despised race, whose only office
is to serve the white man.
I have myself, repeatedly, seen
a colored gentleman & lady, friends
of mine with whom I was travelling, insultingly
whispered, that they 'couldn't
eat at the first table', & that too
at hotels, where all the waiters were
colored men. Yes, such is the
wicked prejudice against the
black man, here at the North,
that no smile of fortune, no wealth
of intellect, no culture of mind,
no refinement of soul, has power
to purchase respect from the
white man. Insult & outrage
meet him at every turn,Judge Taney's decision
that black men have no rights
which white men are bound to respect
is not so wide off the mark of the
spirit & practice of the American people, North
as well as South. Nay; does
it not rather harmonize with
the popular will and action, even
in the so call Free States of the
North? Look over the
By Laws and Regulations of very
nearly all of our popular & respectable
Educational, Literary, Scientific and
Religious Institutions11
Colored persons are not allowed
to visit Public Libraries, - Picture
Galleries, - Academies of Music,
and Fine Arts; - nor may they,
like white men, choose their seats
in fashionable churches, theatres
or popular lecture Halls - or be
admitted as members of Lyceums
and Young Mens Associations. -
In New York City
a colored man may not aspire
to the Office of street lamp lighter.
And, it is against the law of this
glorious Republic, that a colored
man shall hold the reigns of the
horses that carry the Unites States
mails. -- Whenever & wherever
the colored man or woman
presumed to seek other than

12
the most menial employment,
they are repulsed at the very
door, and made to feel
that none of the nobler industrial
avocations belong them. -
If the black man, on the
southern plantation, dare assert
his manhood, by word or act, there
comes to his listening ear, the
crack of the Slave-drivers whip,
and to his naked back, the slave-
drivers merciless lash, deep buried in his
quivering flesh, - nor stays he his
relentless arm, till the warm
blood, gushing, trickles to his very
feet; - Nay; and not unfrequently
till life itself becomes extinct. -
When we, of the North, listen
to the recital, of such monster13
Barbarity, the soul sickens, the
nerves thrill with horror, - the
very life-blood curdles in our veins.
And, yet, what better do we?
While the cruel slave-driver
lacerates the black man's mortal
body, - we, of the north,
flay the spirit, - the immortal
part, - the divine soul, - the
very God in man. -
At the South it is a crime,
punishable with fine & imprisonment,
to teach a black man to read
& write. - Here, at the north,
some of the means of education are
thrown open to him, - intellectual
culture lies within his reach,
he may master the Languages, and
arts & sciences, - he may win the14
prize on essays and orations,
and graduate with highest honors
from Oberlin or M. Grawville: And,
what then? Why, find all the
doors of Law, medical & divinity
schools shut against him, - all
the nobler avenues to wealth,
fame & distinction pre-occupied
by the white man; & every where
is he met, by look, word or
action, you're a black man,
you can't stand on an even
platform with the white man.
Your face tells the tale, - you
belong to a degraded & despised
class, - to an inferior race, The
work of your brains & hands
can't come in competition with
that of the white man's. - Your

15
classic lore, your scientific
knowledge, your artistic skill,
your God-like intellect, your
divine soul, may not be admitted
into the presence-chamber,
even, of the 'superior' white man.
Our only boast, then, over the
south, is, that we give to the poor
down-trodden black man, somewhat
of Culture, that we increase
his sensitiveness to pain, that
we agonize him with the sight
of pleasures, forbidden to him, -
that we quicken his sense of despair
at the frightful inequality of his
lot, - that we add insult to
injury, - that we fan into life
the hopes and aspirations of [the] true
[divine] manhood, and then with cruel,15
murderous hand, crush them into
the mire, - that we tantalize
and torture the refined & cultivated
spirit of the free black man, till
in the very agony of his soul, he
cries, give me back my benumbed
intellect, my insensate heart, -
my clanking chains, - my life-
long bondage to a tyrant master.
Friends, [Fellow Citizens] there
is no respect, for the black man's
rights, in the heart of this nation.
Judge Taney's decision, infamous
as it is, is but the reflection of
the spirit and practice of the
American people, North, as well
as South. -- There are
glorious exceptions, & grant, noble
men, and liberal institutions,17
that recognize the Father-hood
of God, and the Brotherhood of man;
that accord equal rights & privileges
to all of earth's children, irrespective
of color or sex. -- And, yet,
this blackest of all decisions, does
but lay bare to the world's gaze
the still blacker popular heart of
this American Republic.
Let us, then, here at the north,
cease denouncing Judge Taney, [and]
[his infamous decision], and go about
doing the work, that shall prove
to ourselves and the world, that we
believe black men have rights, which
white men are bound to respect.
Let us give to every colored man,
whose foot rests upon our soil, his
inalienable right to Liberty & Equality.

18
The moment the the flying fugitive
touches our northern borders, let his
shackles fall. - Let the Free states, with
one voice, proclaim, 'Slaves cannot
breathe, north of the 'Mason & Dixon Line.'
Let us open to the colored man,
all our schools, from the common
District, to the College; - Let all our
Law, Medical & Divinity schools give to
him, equal rights and privileges with
the white students; - Let us admit
him into all our mechanic shops,
stores, offices, and lucrative business
avocations, to work side by side with
his white brother; - Let him rent
such pew in the church, and occupy
such seat in the theatre, and public
lecture room, as he pleases; - Let
him be admitted to all our19
entertainments, both public & private,
let him share all the accommodations
of our hotels, Stages, Rail
Roads and steamboats, on precisely
the same conditions with the
white man. - Extend to him
all the rights of Citizenship. let
him vote and be voted for, Let
him sit upon the judges bench,
and in the jurors box; send your
Frederick Douglas to Congress, and
compel the south to accept them
as your representatives.
Let all this be done, right manfully,
on our part, and we shall
send up to Judge Taney and his
compeers, a more terrible rebuke, a
more scathing denunciation, than
could possibly go out to them from20
all the resolves, and reresolves
that can be piled on the record
books of the ages. -- Let
the North thus prove to the South, by
her acts, that she fully recognizes
the humanity of the black
man, - that she respects his rights
in all her educational, industrial,
social, religious & political associations,
and she will not only
send a thrill of terror to the
heart of Judge Taney and every
slave-holding lord of the south,
but she will strike a blow to the
accursed system of Slavery itself,
that shall send it, all reeking in the
blood of its millions, howling, and
shrieking, back to the pit from
whence it came.

title: Susan B. Anthony Papers: Speeches and Writings, 1848-1895; 1861; Judge Taney
